We should enable plugging in various JDI clients. This would be very useful to
debug developers for testing purposes, but does not need to be exposed debug users.

Implemented.

The Bootloader class now instantiates the VirtualMachineManager via reflection.
The name of the class is specified in the jdt.debug.core plugin.xml. tools.jar
was also added in the plugin.xml as a runtime library.

Swapping JDI clients requires:
1. Specifying the appropriate fully qualified VirtualMachineManagerImpl in
org.eclipse.jdt.debug.core.plugin.xml
2. Copying the appropriate tools.jar to the org.eclipse.jdt.debug.core plugin
directory. Note that using a tools.jar that is newer than your jre may kill the jre

The problem here is that the 1.3.1 JDI Client doesn't include the new 1.4 JDI
methods (in this case, VirtualMachine.canRedefineClasses()). Our debug model
assumes a 1.4-compatible JDI client.

Unfortunately, Sun's 1.4 JDI client isn't backwards compatible (it kills older
VMs), so this limits our JDI pluggability to 1.4 compliant VMs.

We *could* seed our debug model with JDI client version checks to make our
debugger compatible with older JDI clients, but I'm not sure that it's worth the
effort. I'm more inclined to say that it's Sun's responsibility to make their
1.4 JDI client backwards compatible.
Agreed/Verified. I am able to run the 1.4 client on a 1.4 VM.

The BootStrap class has been updated to return the default (hard-coded)
